text.p: Secretary of State Madeleine Albright came to San Francisco to speak about Asia on Tuesday -- but Cuba intruded.

Three times as she was delivering an address to the Commonwealth Club, Albright was interrupted as protesters -- two groups of two, followed by one woman -- stood and loudly criticised the U.S. embargo of the communist ruled island.

And three times a clearly displeased Albright stopped her speech and delivered a reply that drew applause from the prestigious foreign affairs group as the protesters were hustled out of the San Francisco Hilton Hotel by security guards and police.
"End the U.S. blockade of Cuba," the first pair shouted, displaying a banner.
"I think we can talk about that later," Albright said.
"Stop the U.S. blockade of Cuba," the second group demanded.
"Next time I'll give a speech on Cuba," Albright told them.
The third protester was more severe. "We are opposed to Albright's genocidal policies," she said. At this point, some people in the audience hissed.

Albright quipped, "Now I know why you have so many people at lunch," then spoke seriously about her conviction that "there is nothing romantic about (Fidel) Castro...(who rules) his people in a very dictatorial and totalitarian way (and has been) very vindictive toward the United States."
"We would like to have good and friendly relations with Cuba but it's Cuba that has to change its behaviour, not the United States," she added.
